title: Dissertation: Dissemination in the Ethereum network
objectives:
Crypto-currencies such as Bitcoin and Ethereum have become increasingly popular as a means to exchange digital currencies and also as a platform for executing smart contracts.
The dissemination protocol used to disseminate transactions, blocks and other metadata is crucial for the performance and correctness of the system.
However, several studies show that these protocols have some shortcomings, such as some transactions not reaching everyone.

The goal of this thesis is to study the dissemination protocol of Ethereum, identify possible shortcomings and propose improvements.

The work plan consists of the following steps:
- review of related work
- identification of potential issues in the existing dissemination protocols
- design of techniques to address these issues
- experimental evaluation to assess the effectiveness of the proposed techniques

The expected results are:
- report on, and critical analysis of, the state of the art
- design and evaluation of the proposed techniques
- scientific publication describing the contributions
- master thesis

Bibliography:
[1] Bitcoin: A peer-to-peer electronic cash system. Nakamoto, Satoshi.  (2008).
[2] Ethereum - A Next-Generation Smart Contract and Decentralized Application Platform. White Paper. Ethereum team. 2014-17
[3] On Availability for Blockchain-Based Systems. Weber, Ingo, et al. In IEEE 36th Symposium on Reliable Distributed Systems, 2017.
[4] Information propagation in the Bitcoin network. C. Decker and R. Wattenhofer, IEEE P2P 2013 Proceedings.
requirements: The student should be familiar with advanced distributed systems concepts.Frequency of SEC, DAD and SIRS is a plus.

title: Projecto: Plataforma comunitária para comunicação de dados de sensores IoT
location: Link Consulting, Av. Duque de Ávila, Lisboa (junto ao campus da Alameda).
observations: Responsável na Link: Joel Teixeira, joel.teixeira@linkconsulting.com
objectives:
Plataforma comunitária para relay de comunicação de dados de sensores IoT

Problema
Um dos pilares da construção das smart cities assenta na disponibilização de sensores IoT distribuídos por toda a cidade. A recolha dos dados dos sensores fora da rede tem sido tradicionalmente feita através da rede GSM num processo que onera custos de dispositivos e serviço, reduzindo ainda a autonomia dos dispositivos. Mas uma cidade não se faz sem cidadãos, e grande parte destes transportam dispositivos com capacidade de fazer ponte de comunicações com esses dispositivos, pelo que nasce uma oportunidade: a criação de uma rede que faça justamente essa ponte de comunicações entre sensores e cloud da cidade, rede esta que pode viabilizar o aparecimento de uma grande rede de sensores com baixos custos para a edilidade, num serviço que no futuro pode ser entregue através de uma das aplicações já disponibilizadas (ex: aplicação de gestão de estacionamento ou de utilização de bicicletas partilhadas), podendo ainda ser complementada a cobertura através da utilização de veículos da câmara (ex: bicicletas partilhadas e veículos de serviço).

Resultados esperados:
Pretende-se que o aluno avalie, proponha e implemente uma plataforma e respectivo protocolo capaz de recolher dados de sensores enviando tramas bluetooth advertising que sejam processadas pelos utilizadores que se disponibilizem para fazer o relay da informação. O protocolo a implementar deve centrar-se na segurança da comunicação de forma a impedir ataques de spoofing, garantindo ainda suportar garantia da entrega de acordo com as escolhas do utilizador (ex: delayed relay WiFi para dados não críticos e GSM para dados críticos), assim como respeitar aos limites de utilização acordados.

title: Dissertação: PIM4DevOps: Software Deployment based on Platform-Independent Models
objectives:
Keywords: Deployment; UML/SysML Deployment Diagrams; OSGi; System Architectures; Micro-Services Architectures; DevOps; Continous Integration (CI); Continous Delivery (CD); Infrastructure as code (IAC); Configuration as Code (CAC).

Software deployment is all of the activities that make a software system available for use. The general deployment process consists of several interrelated activities with possible transitions between them. Deployment should be interpreted as a general process that has to be customized according to specific requirements or characteristics, such as the type of infrastructure -- on Premise, on Cloud or Hybrid, or the type of environment -- staging or production software. In the tripple effect of DevOps culture, cloud adoption and continous integration (CI) and continous delivery (CD), the automation of many aspects of software deployment, such as infrastructure provisioning, maintenance and software configuration tasks, gave birth to the concepts of Infrastructure as code (IAC) and Configuration as Code (CAC), allowing to manage the deployments tasks programmatically, with the same rigor that is mandated for any code-based development, including version control and also ensuring repeatability of environment provisioning.  There are currently multiple standardization efforts (e.g., Solution Installation Schema Submission request to W3C, OASIS Solution Deployment Descriptor TC, or OMG Specification for Deployment and Configuration of Component-based Distributed Applications (OMG D&C), or tools that support Deployment tasks, for example: - for provisioning and configuration (IAC/CAC): Vagrant, Ansible, Terraform, SaltStack, Chef, - for orchestration and management: Docker, Mesos, Kubernetes, - for CI/CD: Jenkins, Travis CI, Bamboo, Deployment Automation (Serena DA), Buildmaster - for specific deployment: Open Service Gateway Initiative (OSGi), Java Network Launch Protocol (JNLP). 

For example, the OSGi specification describes a modular system and a service platform for the Java programming language that implements a complete and dynamic component model, something that does not exist in standalone Java/VM environments. Applications or components, coming in the form of bundles for deployment, can be remotely installed, started, stopped, updated, and uninstalled without requiring a reboot; management of Java packages/classes is specified in great detail. Application life cycle management is implemented via APIs that allow for remote downloading of management policies. The service registry allows bundles to detect the addition of new services, or the removal of services, and adapt accordingly. The OSGi specifications have evolved beyond the original focus of service gateways, and are now used in applications ranging from mobile phones to the open-source Eclipse IDE. Other application areas include automobiles, industrial automation, building automation, PDAs, grid computing, entertainment, fleet management and application servers. This project intends to research such deployment specifications, languages and approaches to conduct and support the design of a new Platform-independent Language for software Deployment (PL4D). This language shall support the specification of computational nodes, components and artifacts, but also emerging concepts related with dynamic environments, virtual machines, containers and micro-services architectures and orchestration. 
Finally the results obtained shall be validated based on real scenarios to be defined.

Reference Paper:  J. Wettinger, U. Breitenbücher and F. Leymann, DevOpSlang - Bridging the Gap Between Development and Operations, in Proceedings of the 3rd European Conference on Service-Oriented and Cloud Computing (ESOCC 2014), https://goo.gl/8CAMqs

title: Dissertação: Permissioned Blockchain Simulator
supervisors: Miguel Nuno Dias Alves Pupo Correia (100%)
objectives:
Blockchain is a promising new technology that is generating a vast interest world-wide, including Portugal, with important initiatives from the government, Banco de Portugal, and several others [U16, P17]. A blockchain or distributed ledger is an ordered log (“chain”) of transactions that runs in several nodes connected by the Internet, to which it is possible to append new transactions, but not modify those already logged. The original blockchain was the core of the Bitcoin cryptocurrency [N08], but today the term is used generically. There are two major families of blockchains: permissionless blockchains that can be joined by any node that runs compatible software (e.g., Bitcoin, Ethereum); permissioned blockchains that are closed to authorized participants (e.g., Ethereum Fabric) [P17]. The first tend to be highly scalable and very slow, whereas the second scale badly but are efficient.
 
Network and distributed system simulators are important tools to evaluate the performance of protocols and systems in a large set of conditions. These simulators provide an environment in which to implement and run these protocols in a way that is far simpler than real systems. Simulators like The One [K+09], PeerSim [MJ09], and CloudSim [C+11] are playing an important role in the development of protocols and systems respectively for opportunistic networks, peer-to-peer networks, and cloud computing.
 
We are currently designing and implementing a simulator for blockchains and cryptocurrencies called BlockSim that allows such systems to be implemented in a simple way and have their performance evaluated in different conditions. Currently this system is able to simulate only two permissionless blockchains, Bitcoin and Ethereum.

The objective of the project is to produce a second, more advanced, version of BlockSim, that is able to simulate also permissioned blockchains. That new simulator will be able to simulate at least Hyperledger Fabric [A+18, SBV18], which is arguably the most popular permissioned blockchain technology. The simulator will be used to compare versions of Hyperledger Fabric with different configurations.

A research paper is expected to be published based on the results of the thesis.
 
 
References:
 
[A+18] Androulaki, Elli, et al. "Hyperledger fabric: a distributed operating system for permissioned blockchains." Proceedings of the Thirteenth EuroSys Conference. ACM, 2018.

[C+11] R. Calheiros et al., “CloudSim: a toolkit for modeling and simulation of cloud computing environments and evaluation of resource provisioning algorithms”, Software Practice & Experience, 2011.

[K+09] A. Keränen et al., “The ONE simulator for DTN protocol evaluation”, SIMUTools 2009.
 
[MJ09] A. Montresor and M. Jelasity, “PeerSim: A Scalable P2P Simulator”, P2P 2009.

[N08] Nakamoto, Satoshi. "Bitcoin: A peer-to-peer electronic cash system." (2008).

[P17] Peck, Morgen E. "Blockchains: How they work and why they'll change the world." IEEE Spectrum 54.10 (2017): 26-35.
 
[S+08] A. Singh et al., “BFT Protocols Under Fire”, NSDI 2008.

[SBV18] Sousa, Joao, Alysson Bessani, and Marko Vukolić. "A byzantine fault-tolerant ordering service for the hyperledger fabric blockchain platform.” In Proceedings of DSN 2018.

[U16] Underwood, Sarah. "Blockchain beyond bitcoin." Communications of the ACM 59.11 (2016): 15-17.

title: DISSERTAÇÃO : Segmentação de imagens de satélite com redes neuronais profundas
observations:
Uma aluna do MEIC de nome Maria Dias mostrou já interesse na realização deste trabalho de mestrado.

A orientação dos trabalhos caberá a Bruno Martins do DEI/IST e INESC-ID, e a Jacinto Estima do INESC-ID. O trabalho involverá ainda a colaboração com outros investigadores participantes no projecto "MIning MUlti-source and MUlti-modal geo-referenced information", do INESC-ID e da NOVA-LINCS.

Os alunos interessados na realização deste trabalho devem contactar o Prof. Bruno Martins (i.e., bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt), no sentido de obterem esclarecimentos adicionais e por forma a agendar uma entrevista inicial.
objectives:
Com o aumento de projetos de observação da Terra envolvendo o lançamento de satélites, assim como a crescente disponibilidade de aviões e veículos aéreos não tripulados (UAVs), temos que imagens da superfície da Terra com uma alta resolução estão agora acessíveis a um custo razoável. A interpretação automática destes dados (i.e., imagens/produtos de detecção remota) de alta resolução é uma tarefa de importante para uma ampla gama de aplicações práticas, incluindo o mapeamento da cobertura do terreno, o planeamento urbano, a monitorização de tráfego, ou a quantificação do potencial de energia solar foto-voltaica em telhados.

Um passo crucial para a análise dos conteúdos de imagens de detecção remota de alta resolução é a segmentação semântica das imagens para a extração automática de objetos urbanos. Esta tarefa consiste em classificar cada pixel na imagem com a categoria semântica do objeto ao qual o pixel pertence. A tarefa é particularmente desafiante devido à aparência muito heterogénea de objetos como edifícios, ruas, árvores, e/ou carros em dados de alta resolução, o que leva a uma alta variação intra-classe enquanto que a variação entre classes é baixa.

Este projeto de mestrado abordará o desenvolvimento de métodos de "deep learning" para a segmentação semântica de imagens de detecção remota, em ambiente urbano e de alta resolução, visando aplicações para o mapeamento da cobertura do terreno. O candidato explorará a aplicação de arquiteturas neuronais modernas (por exemplo, redes de cápsulas conforme descritas no documento "Capsules for Object Segmentation" -- https://arxiv.org/abs/1804.04241 -- ou variações da arquitetura transformer, como as descritas no artigo "Dense Transformer Networks" -- https://arxiv.org/abs/1705.08881). Experiências comparativas, envolvendo diferentes modelos, serão feitas usando os conjuntos de dados para segmentação semântica 2D do ISPRS, referentes às cidades de Vaihingen (http://www2.isprs.org/commissions/comm3/wg4/2d-sem-label-vaihingen.html) e Potsdam (http : //www2.isprs.org/commissions/comm3/wg4/2d-sem-label-potsdam.html), assim como com o conjunto de dados de classificação de imagens aéreas do INRIA (https://project.inria.fr/aerialimagelabeling/).
requirements:
O trabalho não deve ser seleccionado por alunos com disciplinas em atraso, ou com compromissos profissionais no período de execução dos trabalhos.
Valoriza-se conhecimento prévio em aprendizagem automática, extracção de informação, detecção remota, e sistemas de informação geográfica (e.g., através de disciplinas realizadas no contexto do curso de mestrado). A execução dos trabalhos envolverá o desenvolvimento de software, esperando-se no entanto que venham a ser usadas bancadas de software já existentes para a realização de experiências com algoritmos de aprendizagem automática, tais como as bibliotecas PyTorch ou keras.io.

Aos alunos interessados em obter mais informações sobre as técnicas a serem estudadas/desenvolvidas no contexto deste trabalho aconselha-se a leitura dos artigos "Beyond RGB: Very High Resolution Urban Remote Sensing With Multimodal Deep Networks" (https://arxiv.org/abs/1711.08681), "RiFCN: Recurrent Network in Fully Convolutional Network for Semantic Segmentation of High Resolution Remote Sensing Images" (https://arxiv.org/abs/1805.02091) e "Symmetrical Dense-Shortcut Deep Fully Convolutional Networks for Semantic Segmentation of Very-High-Resolution Remote Sensing Images" (https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8326706/).

title: [Dissertation] DeepData: Program Synthesis in the Azores Deep Sea
observations: Possibility of being awarded a grant in the second term.
objectives: The DeepData project aims to gather data of the Azores deep sea. The goal of this work is to develop a formal methods-based tool for automated data reshaping to be integrated with a web-based database. Many tasks performed by researchers in Azores require the data to be reshaped into a form that is suitable for analysis. For example, before building predictive models the data must be in a "tidy" format, where each variable corresponds to a column and each row represents an observation. Automated tools developed in DeepData will use input-output examples to synthesize scripts that can automate tedious and time-consuming data transformation tasks.
requirements: Background in Data Science and Formal Methods.

title: Dissertação: Using read and write sets for microservices architecture migration
observations: Atribuído a Nuno Santos (81703)
objectives:
The microservices architecture allows the existence of several autonomous agile development teams but result in a distributed system where the aspect of consistency becomes critical, the CAP theorem.

The goal of this thesis is on how to assist developers in the migration process from a monolithic application to a microservices architecture. Therefore it is necessary to identify the transactional bounded contexts that exists in the monolithic application and characterize the types of eventual consistency between them. The final tool should provide maps that suggest possible bounded contexts in a large transactional domain.
requirements:
The work will be done on the results of a previous MSc thesis, where a tool was developed that collects which domain entities are accessed by each one of the application's controllers, uses a similarity measure to define clusters, and provides a user interface to allow the software developer analyse different partitioning hypothesis.
In this thesis we intend to enriched the previous work with the information about the read and write sets associated with each one the controllers to infer particular patterns of interaction among microservices.

title: Projeto - RainDrops Keep Falling
observations: Numa óptica centrada no utilizador, pretende-se criar uma solução responsiva para dispositivos móveis com base numa app já existente que permita a agricultores saber quando e quanto regar culturas, fundindo informação local, obtida por sondas (humidade, transpiração) ou pelo utilizador, com informação de previsões a médio prazo através de um serviço web existente e de registos de ocorrências. A app a criar terá como ponto de partida uma app piloto já desenvolvida e cuja arquitectura será objecto de melhorias.

A solução deve permitir programar a rega, tendo em conta, por exemplo, a poupança de energia. e controlar instalações de rega, a partir de um protótipo já desenvolvido.

title: Projeto: InterfaceTrainer - A Personal Assistant to Help with User Frustration
objectives: Alguns utilizadores param de usar um produto porque existe uma interface ou um elemento de interação que os deixa frustrados ou porque não recebem a ajuda de que precisam, o que também os deixa frustrados. O objetivo deste trabalho é  criar um assistente pessoal que ajuda os utilizadores com base na sua frustração. Primeiro, é necessário modelar um classificador que possa detetar em tempo real o estado mental de frustração do utilizador. Em segundo lugar, uma estrutura de controlador que adapta a interface com base no estado mental do mesmo. Por último, uma interface com um componente adaptativo focado em auxiliar o utilizador.
requirements: Frequência da disciplina de IPM; Frequência de VI e CCU (não obrigatório mas relevante).

title: Dissertation: Plasma simulation using modern high-level HPC programming platforms
observations: Possibility of a research grant
objectives:
In the context of the plasma research community, the Particle-In-Cell (PIC) method is a well studied means of investigating the behaviour of different kinds of systems involving electrons, ions, neutrals, molecules, dust particles, etc. 
While this is currently one of the most active problems in high-performance computing (HPC), the most successful PIC programs consist of handcrafted code, which is manually fine-tuned for a specific supercomputer on which it was originally developed. This constitutes a major obstacle portability, especially when the goal is to port the PIC programs to modern extreme-scale machines, comprised of various multi-core nodes, interconnected by a complex topology.
Recently, some high-level programming platforms for HPC have emerged, like opmSS, GASPI and ArgoDSM. These platforms hide many complex problems away from the programmer, promising unprecedented portability and performance in complex architectures. This claim is, however, to be proven with realistic applications.
The goal of this thesis is to study what effective benefits such high-level platforms may bring to PIC. Departing from a lower-level solution of PIC, the thesis will implement variants of that solution on high-level platforms. An experimental evaluations will shed new light on the actual gains (and costs) of the high-level approaches.
requirements: The student should be familiar with advanced concepts on computer architectures, concurrent programming and operating systems.

title: Dissertação: Optimização de um acelerador de construção de imagens SAR (via satélite)
observations:
Mais info: 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_aperture_radar
objectives:
SAR é uma técnica usada para construir imagens 2D/3D de alta resolução de objetos ou cenas, a partir de um equipamento móvel, como uma aeronave ou satélite. Isso é conseguido através da transmissão de sequências de pulsos via ondas de rádio por uma antena para um alvo e recebendo o eco de cada pulso. SAR é independente da altitude de voo, condições meteorológicas e hora do dia.
SAR tornou-se popular pelas suas diversas aplicações, tais como nos sectores aeroespacial, militar, segurança, meteorologia, geologia, agricultura, hidrologia e monitorização do ambiente. 
A principal restrição computacional na implementação de SAR como um sistema autónomo é o processamento de sinal extremo necessário para criar uma imagem a partir dos dados de eco recebidos.
Este trabalho visa implementar arquiteturas de computação reconfiguráveis dedicadas e otimizadas (FPGA) para imagens SAR em tempo-real, recorrendo a programação de alto-nível OpenCl.

O OpenCL é uma linguagem de programação para sistemas heterogéneos (GPU, FPGA, etc.) e permite abstrair os detalhes do hardware ao mesmo tempo que explora o paralelismo oferecido por ele.
O âmbito desta tese é o desenvolvimento de uma aplicação eficiente usando algoritmos de SAR, explorando o paralelismo oferecido pela tecnologia reconfigurável (FPGAs), programada em OpenCL para aumentar a performance da execução do algoritmo.
Resultado esperado: Protótipo da arquitectura em FPGA a executar a aplicação de demonstração.
requirements: São requisitos para a candidatura ao trabalho os conhecimentos fundamentais de projecto de sistemas digitais e de arquitectura de computadores, adquiridos nas cadeiras de Introdução às Arquitecturas de Computadores e Organização de Computadores.

title: Dissertação: Enterprise Architecture Dynamic Evolution Decision using Simulation and Machine Learning
objectives:
https://sites.google.com/view/teses-si-sergioguerreiro/home/enterprise-architecture-dynamic-evolution-decision-using-simulation-and-ml?authuser=0

Enterprise architecture (EA) is a discipline that provides management with appropriate indicators and controls to steer and model the enterprise during change. However, the management of such change is a challenging task for enterprise architects due to the complex dependencies amongst EA models when evolving from initial (As-is) to posterior (To-be) states. 
The challenge is to research an approach supporting design decision during EA evolution, by assisting enterprise architects in computing best alternatives to a posterior state. In doing so, the EA artifacts dependencies are modelled and their evolution during change identified. This model is, then, processed using a control schema to inform EA design decisions. 

Resultados Esperados: 
1. Levantamento de Estado da Arte sobre soluções e implementações conhecidas na comunidade científica e empresarial.
2. Proposta de modelo conceptual que integre os modelos de representação de Enterprise Architecture com os processos de decisão organizacionais.
3. Definição, desenvolvimento e teste de ambiente para simulação das diversas alternativas arquitecturais, de acordo com critério(s) de avaliação pré-definido.
4. Avaliação do modelo conceptual anterior por (i) instanciação num ambiente real no contexto empresarial e (ii) instanciação em ambiente simulado, usando design science research (DSR). 
5. Publicação de artigo(s) ao longo da execução da tese.

Referências a trabalho prévio:
Winter, R. Establishing Architectural Thinking in (Large) Organizations. PoEM’16 keynote.
Guerreiro, S., Gaaloul, K. (-). A Decision-Making Approach for Enterprise Architecture Evolution using Simulation, In press, International Journal of Operational Research (IJOR) - Inderscience, ISSN 17457645, 17457653.
requirements: Disciplinas de sistemas de informação

title: Dissertação: EXPLAINABILITY IN MULTIVARIATE TIMESERIES
objectives:
We are entering a new world of information, where Artificial Intelligence is taking the reins.
Some call it the 'new electricity', and with no surprise. 
The unmeasurable potential of A.I. is bringing us intelligence on our businesses, and daily lives. 
The span of influence of A.I. has already spread its tentacles around the world and thus taking us into a new era.

This new era brings about change. According to these changes that are occurring in our world,
responsible entities are taking action. The new GDPR law, taking effect in Europe, states in Article 22 that "Automated individual decision-making, including profiling,” concerns the use of data in decision-making that affects individuals, such as a person applying for a loan. 

In a world where A.I. models are making decisions for humans, the answer to "Why wasn't I offered this loan?" can never be "Because the model said so.". Taking this into account, it is easy to conclude that A.I. explainability (to be able to answer WHY a model made a certain decision) is becoming very important.

Therefore this dissertation tackles A.I. explainability/interpretability and focuses on one type of problem - Time series. Time series is data that has a temporal dimension to it. This could be the number of sales within a month, for instance. 

The objective of this thesis is to investigate existing methods for extracting knowledge of models trained on temporal data, and hopefully come up with new ones.
requirements: SAD
areas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems

title: [Dissertação] Gardens of AI: Life-Long Artificial Intelligence
location: The work will be conducted in the GAIPS Group of INESC-ID, located in IST TagusPark (Alameda also possible)
observations:
- Motivation -
Classical logical based A.I. methods considered a very complex and time consuming definition of the knowledge domain and representation. Modern methods from control and behavioral robotics avoid the definition of the knowledge domain but are much more limited in terms of generalization and task switching. We would like to be able to merge the qualities of both approach generalization of logical based systems with the faster adaptability of behavioral approaches. In the gardens of AI [2] the authors propose and interactive approach to such problem.

- Goals -
In this project we will develop methods to learn symbols from interaction between an intelligent agent, the environment and a teacher. The agent will learn multiple symbols [3] that will be pruned and label by the teacher [2], and then the system will try to plan using such symbols. To propose to the user new symbols the system can rely on intrinsic motivation approaches [5] or active learning [6]. An interesting setup to test this ideas is the project-malmo system [1].



- References -

1.: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/project/project-malmo/
2.	Selfridge, Oliver G. "The gardens of learning: a vision for AI." AI Magazine 14.2 (1993): 36.
3.	Sutton, Richard S., et al. "Horde: A scalable real-time architecture for learning knowledge from unsupervised sensorimotor interaction." The 10th International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems-Volume 2. International Foundation for Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems, 2011.
4.	Singh, Satinder P., Andrew G. Barto, and Nuttapong Chentanez. "Intrinsically Motivated Reinforcement Learning." NIPS. Vol. 17. No. 2. 2004.
5.	Barto, Andrew G., Satinder Singh, and Nuttapong Chentanez. "Intrinsically motivated learning of hierarchical collections of skills." Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Development and Learning. 2004.
6.	Kulick, J., Toussaint, M., Lang, T., & Lopes, M. (2013, August). Active Learning for Teaching a Robot Grounded Relational Symbols. In IJCAI.
objectives:
During the thesis work, the student is expected to:
•	Learn about reinforcement learning, basic deep learning
•	Learn about symbol learning methods and symbol abstraction methods
•	Develop new interactive forms of state abstraction for solving complex games (e.g. minecraft)
requirements: The student needs to have very good programming skills, knowledge of machine learning methods, specially reinforcement learning, and interest in novel machine learning approaches.

title: Dissertação: Enterprise Dynamic Systems Control @ EAMS
objectives:
Enterprise Dynamic Systems Control (EDSC) aims at detecting, judging and acting in the scope of the business processes compliance. A three-time window division is considered: ex-ante – concerning the modelling of the business processes using standard specification languages (e.g., ArchiMate, BPMN, PetriNets, UML, DEMO, MEMO, etc.); exdure – concerning the software support to the business processes operation (e.g., Model Driven Environments); and expost – concerning the improvement of the ex-dure and ex-ante encompassing full and partial observations. Ex-ante, exdure and ex-post are integrated as a control loop to guarantee the business transactions expected behaviour.
So far, the overall EDSC conceptualization [1] [3] is successfully validated using an ontological approach [2]. Moreover, EDSC is already implemented and published for ex-post counterpart with full and partial observation capabilities.
This proposal is an effort to develop a multiplatform software tool prototype that implements the EDSC scientific proposal with plugged-in compliance algorithms is expected

Resultados Esperados: 
1. Levantamento de Estado da Arte sobre soluções e implementações conhecidas na comunidade científica e empresarial.
2. Proposta de modelo conceptual que integre EDSC com EAMS.
3. Definição, desenvolvimento e teste de ambiente para simulação das diversas alternativas arquitecturais, de acordo com critério(s) de avaliação pré-definido.
4. Avaliação do modelo conceptual anterior por (i) instanciação num ambiente real no contexto empresarial e (ii) instanciação em ambiente simulado, usando design science research (DSR). 
5. Publicação de artigo(s) ao longo da execução da tese.

Referências a trabalho prévio:
[1] Guerreiro, S., Tribolet, J. (2013). CONCEPTUALIZING ENTERPRISE DYNAMIC SYSTEMS CONTROL FOR RUN-TIME BUSINESS TRANSACTIONS, Proceedings of 21st European Conference on Information Systems (ECIS 2013), ISBN: 978-90-393-6112-2, paper 393, Utrecht, Netherlands, June, http://aisel.aisnet.org/ecis2013_rip/5/,
[2] Guerreiro, S., Vasconcelos, A., Tribolet, J. (2012). Enterprise dynamic systems control enforcement of run-time business transactions, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg, LNBIP 110 series Lecture Notes in Business Information Processing, Enterprise Engineering Working Conference 2012 (EEWC 2012), Delft, Netherlands, pp. 46--60, DOI: 10.1007/978-3-642-29903-24, Print ISBN: 978-3-642-29902-5, Online ISBN: 978-3-642- 29903-2, ISSN: 1865-1348, http://goo.gl/TSZHr
[3] Guerreiro, S. (2018). Informed Decision-Making with Enterprise Dynamic Systems Control, Encyclopedia of Information Science and Technology, fourth edition, Systems and Software Engineering, IGI Global, pp.2154--2165, DOI: 10.4018/978-1-5225-2255-3.ch187.
